repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Bank Restructuring Facility
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated highly
            satisfactory The sustainability of the loan's
            short-term objectives is highly likely, while securing
            long-term objectives regarding access to credit is less
            certain. Overall sustainability of the policy reforms is,
            therefore, rated likely. Both World Bank and Borrower
            performances are assessed as satisfactory. Lessons learned
            include the following: Set limited objectives-it is more
            realistic to support a program of reforms with a number of
            sequential operations that can be approved based on the
            success of the previous ones. Banking restructuring
            operations should disburse against the completed resolution
            of specific banks' cases, not against the promise of
            future actions which may not materialize. Ensure that the
            main implementing agency is the main recipient of the Bank
            resources. Bank support should come only after a political
            consensus in favor of restructuring banks and facing past
            losses has been achieved. Tools of evaluation may need to be
            better adapted to suit sequential operations within a
            broader program. Prior attempts to "contain" the
            banking crisis were excessively focused on "accounting
            solutions" (i.e., exchange of bad loans for government
            paper) with no cash flow impact. The "least cash
            solution" was not the "least cost solution"
            and several banks, full of government paper, had to be
            interervened since their cash flow continued to deteriorate.

5086490.majtheme: Economic management,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Bank Restructuring Facility
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Bank Restructuring Facility
            Adjustment Loan Project for Mexico supports the first stage
            of the government's bank restructuring program, which
            includes legal reforms to improve incentives in the banking
            center; regulatory reforms to improve bank capitalization
            and soundness, such as improved disclosure, an improved
            definition of risk weighted assets; classification and new
            provisioning rules; improved accounting practices and
            standards; the restructuring, sale, merger, or liquidation
            of five banks under the restructuring program for the Bank
            Savings Protection Institute (IPAB). The Bank funds
            complement other sources of financing available to IPAB:
            fiscal transfers, proceeds from asset disposal/recovery, and
            fees from deposit insurance premiums. The loan is disbursed
            in three tranches, the first upon loan signing in support of
            front reform measures already taken by the Mexican
            authorities, and two floating tranches that will each be
            disbursed against agreed tranche conditions.
